Introduction

This Policy sets out Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust's ( ‘the Trust's') commitment to, so far as is reasonably practicable; ensure that there is a management regime for the safe design, installation, and operational management of electrical plant, equipment and systems.

In addition the Trust recognises its duty of care for the safety of staff and patients under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act, the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations and the Electricity at Work Regulations to ensure that any hazards or risks are identified and controlled.

The Trust has several types of fixed electrical installations 415V main distribution systems, 240V lighting and power outlets, security and fire alarms and information technology fixed installations. In addition there are varying types of portable electrical appliance both medical equipment and the equipment in offices and public areas.

It is important that electrical systems function safely and correctly, have adequate protection and do not exceed their design limits. The assurance of safe and reliable operation can only be achieved through a regime of regular inspection and testing of such systems and equipment and the implementation of appropriate maintenance works. This Policy applies to all persons (service users, staff, members of the public and contractors) who may be affected by the use of electricity or electrical equipment within Trust occupied premises. It also applies to all activities associated with electricity when employees and/or contractors undertake works at within Trust occupied premises.
There are other sources of regulatory and best practice guidance relating to electrical systems. See References section.
The combined intention of these documents is to ensure:
Continued availability of supply;
Integrity and safety in design;
Good installation and commissioning practice;
Adequate maintenance and safe systems of use.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Detail the Trust's policy to achieve safety in all its electrical activities in compliance with it legal and statutory obligations.
Ensure staff and other affected by this policy are aware their duties
ensure the provision of safe electrical equipment which is insulated, earthed or otherwise suitably protected, thereby ensuring the safety of the user
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

Low Voltage: A potential not exceeding A) 1000V ac or 1500V dc between conductors, or B) 600V ac or 900V dc between a conductor and earth. N.B. Refer to EFM–19 ‘Electricity (LV) Safety Rules Procedure' which supports safe operational procedure for conducting works on L.V. electrical systems
High Voltage: A potential normally exceeding low voltage
Item of equipment which is not part of a fixed installation but is, or is intended to be, connected to a fixed installation, or generator, by means of a flexible cable, plug and socket

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities (i.e. Medicines Committees)
Health and Safety Committee
Feed via chair assurance to the Trust Board regarding compliance with statutory legislation.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive) Chief Executive (Duty Holder)
Has the overall responsibility for health and safety and the implementation of this policy within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and remote premises under the Trust's responsibility.
Ensure compliance with statutory legislation, Approved Codes of Practice and Department of Health requirements regarding electrical safety.
Ensure appropriate funds are available to carry out capital and revenue works.

Will assume the role of ‘Duty Holder' on whom the Electricity at Work Regulations 1989 imposes a duty relating to safety. This responsibility is delegated to the Senior Director of Estates and Facilities
Designated Person

The Designated Person, appointed by the Chief Executive, who has the overall authority and responsibility for the electrical systems within the Trust premises and has a duty under the Health and Safety at Work etc Act 1974 to prepare and issue a general policy statement on health and safety at work including the organisation and arrangements to carry out that policy.

The Designated Person shall appoint in writing an Authorising Engineer (AE) for the low voltage system that the Trust retain the responsibility to manage. The Authorising Engineer will ideally be a Chartered Electrical Engineer, who is competent to advise on safety arrangements for defined low voltage electrical systems. The AE should be independent of the Trust and will also assess the suitability and appointment of all Authorised Persons - Electrical.
Authorising Engineer (AE)
Specific responsibilities assigned to AE are:
Responsible for implementing, administering and monitoring the application to the Health Technical Memorandum's HTM06-02 and HTM06-03.
Access and recommend and appoint in writing sufficient Authorised Persons HV and LV to provide the necessary cover for all systems and installation for which management has responsibility
Define the exact extent of the systems and installations for which each Authorised Persons HV and LV is responsible
If necessary, recommend the suspension or cancellation of the appointment of an Authorised Person HV and LV and withdraw the certification.
Maintain a register of all Authorised Persons HV and LV and make available to the Designated Person. This record to be kept up to date and valid.
Ensure that candidates for appointment as Authorised persons HV and LV:
- Satisfy the qualification requirements
- Satisfy the training and familiarisation requirements
- Can demonstrate adequate knowledge of each system, installation and type of equipment for which authorisation is sought
- Have satisfied the Authorising Engineer HV and LV as to their competence and ability
Authorised Person (HV or LV)
Appointed by the Designated Person on the recommendation of the Authorising Engineer in writing.
Is an electrical engineer with the required knowledge, training and experience
Responsible for the practical implementation and operation of guidance HTM06- 02 and HTM06-03 and the systems and installations for which the Authorised Person HV and or LV has been appointed.

Appoint in writing of competent persons HV and LV and maintain a register of all appointments and make available to the Designated Person. Records will be kept by the Designated Person and will be audited on an annual basis
Co-operate with the Authorising Engineer HV and or LV in matters of policy concerning HV and or LV systems
Shall appoint the Competent Persons (HV & LV)

Approval of electrical contractors to undertake work for the Trust shall be by the Authorised Person only. This will be conducted as section 4 of the HTM06 – 02 and HTM06 – 03 Electrical safety guidance, appointment of contractors' competent person
Maintain a register of all Competent Persons HV and LV and make available to the Designated Person. This record to be kept up to date and valid.
Competent Persons (HV or LV)
The Competent Person(s) HV and or LV shall comply with this safety policy and operation of guidance HTM06-02 and HTM06-03.
Shall be appointed by the Authorised Person (HV & LV)
Will be appointed for defined work, possessing the necessary technical knowledge, skill and experience relevant to the nature of the work to be undertaken.

Competent Persons are contractors and trades staff who have received adequate training and have sufficient experience to operate, maintain, inspect and test low voltage electrical systems in a safe and effective manner. Duties include:
Accompanying Safety Person (HV & LV)
Must not directly be involved with the work or test being carried out, but must have adequate knowledge, experience to avoid danger
Required to observe and prevent unauthorised interruption of the work or test, and be able to apply first aid or summon assistance
Must be first aid trained
Project Managers
Must ensure that all new works shall comply with this electrical safety policy and all current legislation.
Ensure the contractors they employ adhere to this and other Trust policies and procedures and HTM's
Provide adequate information to the Authorised Persons (HV or LV) so the new installations can be accessed and approved for connection into the system to which they are responsible.
Commissioning certificates and handover documentation will be handed to the Authorised Persons (HV or LV) on completion and handover of the project. Copies of which will be held electronically.
Must consult with Fire Safety Advisor to ensure planned electrical works do not compromise integrity of fire compartments throughout Trust buildings.
Review Asbestos Register
Directorate / Service Leads and Managers
Ensure that staff are made aware of the contents of this policy and understand their responsibilities to comply with its contents
To implement this policy and procedure within their areas of responsibility
Provide access at all reasonable times to properties and equipment in order that Trust staff and Contractors can discharge their duties under this policy
Report electrical circuits or equipment in need of repair to EFM Helpdesk
Make available electrical systems or equipment to carry out repairs
Provide access to systems for the purpose of routine testing and inspection

Ensure any electrical equipment delivered to and for use in the Trust has been tested and cleared for use by the EFM Maintenance Service, I.T., Medical Equipment Maintenance Services i.e. equipment must be tested before use
Provide access to portable electrical equipment for testing and inspecting at
mutually convenient times.
Ensure PPM's (including statutory) are undertaken.
All Staff
Adhere to this policy and others relating to electricity in place within the Trust.
Ensure all relevant safe working practices are followed and take adequate precautions where necessary to prevent the risk of personal injury or death from electrical shock.
Report any electrical faults or other shortfalls to EFM Helpdesk
Report all incidents and accidents on DATIX in line with the Trust policy
Contractors (Specific responsibilities)
Contractors and sub-contractors will a hold a suitable level of competence, by training, certification, knowledge and experience.
All contractors must ensure that their employees who work on Trust managed properties possess the appropriate level of technical knowledge and experience to enable them to discharge their duties.
Where a specialist contractor has been appointed under contract by the Trust Management, the contractor shall be required to comply with:
Contractors will liaise with the Trust's HV or LV Authorised Person who will agree isolation procedures for work on the electrical system.

Where HV work is to be undertaken by contractors then the handover documentation will be under HTM06-02 controlled by the HV Authorised person. Operational procedures of the contractor can then be used under agreement with the site HV Authorised person and documented recorded accordingly.

Contractors employed by the Trust for work on its LV system will comply with the requirements of the 18th Edition lEE Wiring Regulations BS 7671: 2008 and will complete a completion and inspection certificate that meets the Trust's requirements.
Contractors must provide written assurance that all their staff are competent in carrying out the required work schedule.
Fixed electrical system - low voltage
Periodic Testing of LV System

All fixed LV electrical systems owned by the Trust shall be periodically inspected and tested in accordance with BS 7671.2008 (18th Edition lEE Wiring Regulations). The frequency of fixed wiring inspection and testing should not exceed 5 years.
All testing must comply with Health Technical Memorandum HTM 06-02.
Circuit Identification – LV

All LV switchgear and distribution boards shall be uniquely identified by securely attached and prominent labels. Each distribution board shall have an on-site circuit chart that allows accurate and easy identification of all circuits connected to the switchboard. Numbering to be issued by Project Team (MICAD)
Final circuit outlets or switches shall also be labelled to reference them to their controlling switch/fuse and distribution board, both internally and externally.
LV schematic diagrams showing the Trusts LV electrical system layout and circuit/switchgear identification references shall be provided and updated as necessary.
New Works or additions – LV
All new LV work including minor additions shall be carried out in accordance with BS 7671, 2008 (18th Edition lEE Wiring Regulations).
Testing and records for such work shall be as detailed:
New work
Minor work (on an existing circuit)
Any additional/project work (no matter how small) must accompanied by certification updated drawings and manuals at handover.
Fixed Equipment Maintenance – LV

All low voltage equipment (e.g. ventilation systems, industrial boiler plant, lifts, industrial compressors etc) shall be regularly inspected, serviced and tested to ensure that it is maintained in a safe and serviceable condition. Test periods shall not exceed  months.
LV Switchgear
All LV Switchgear shall be maintained to ensure its safety and operational capability is maintained. Maintenance intervals shall not exceed the following periods:
Visual inspection every 5 years
Thermo graphic survey every year on heavily loaded and/or operationally sensitive units
High voltage
Equipment Maintenance – High Voltage (HV)

When establishing the maintenance regimes the HV AP must take into account the duty imposed on the equipment, the environmental conditions and the manufacturer's recommendations. All new high voltage work shall be fully commissioned and tested to ensure it functions correctly and to specification.
All HV switchgear and plant shall be maintained to ensure its safety and operation capability is maintained. Maintenance intervals shall not exceed the following periods:
All equipment:
General inspection annually
Switchgear:
4 years for indoor equipment, 1 year for outdoor equipment
All switchgear should be operated on a  monthly basis
Transformers:
Oil tests every 6 years (every year if acidity suspected)
Tripping battery:
Full maintenance every 6 years
Routine maintenance every 3 months
New Works and Additions – HV
All new HV work shall be commission tested to ensure its capability and correct functioning.
Standby emergency generators
All fixed LV standby emergency generators shall be maintained, tested and fuelled to ensure their correct operation in the event of mains failure. All as detailed in the Electrical procedure
The fuel storage of each generator connected fuel tank shall provide for a minimum of 10 hours running at the full rating of the generator. Additional bulk fuel storage
with backup from fuel deliveries to allow a minimum ofhours full load running of each generator shall be arranged.
Fixed uninterruptible power systems (UPS - battery operated)
All UPS systems shall be regularly maintained in accordance with manufactures/installers recommendations to ensure their correct functioning and safe operation.

In the event of a mains failure (or disconnection) and subsequent standby generator operation to restore supply all connected emergency lighting systems shall be regularly monitored to ensure correct synchronisation of rectifier/invertor circuitry i.e. to confirm UPS system does not go into battery operation due to hunting of generator frequency and/or voltage.

If generator control is such that severe hunting does occur (UPS alternating between normal and battery discharge) then it will not be possible to select mains by-pass on the UPS system (static switch will not allow by-pass with mains hunting until batteries discharged) so the UPS may fully discharge unless action is taken. Advice must be taken from an Authorised Person as to appropriate action, which could involve load disconnection and/or generator shutdown.
Combined heat and power systems (CHP systems)
CHP systems are arranged to operate in parallel with the mains electrical supply and to shut down in the event of a mains failure.
All such systems shall be regularly maintained in accordance with manufacturers/installers recommendations to ensure their correct functioning and safe operation.
Inspection and Testing

All fixed electrical plant and installation (s) must be routinely inspected and tested, in accordance with current legislation and good electrical practice. All ‘portable' equipment i.e. Hand held equipment that is connected to the electricity supply with a plug, and Moveable equipment that is 18 kgs or less and is not fixed or, equipment with wheels, castors or other means to facilitate movement by the operator as required must be inspected and\or tested at installation and thereafter determine by process of risk assessment. Records of the portable electrical testing (PAT) inspections must be managed and kept by Estates Department.
In between recorded checks, users must regularly carry out a visual inspection and report any perceived defect.
The appropriate manager from each area of the Trust must ensure that a comprehensive list of portable electrical equipment is kept, updated and available at time of inspection.

After the recorded check, and repair if necessary, the checker must attach to the equipment a label saying Tested for Electrical Safety and insert the date that the test is next due. Equipment found with no label or a label which is overdue must not be used in any circumstances. The manager must then organise a test of that equipment.
Permit to work
The following works carried out on electrical equipment located on Trust Premises shall be subject to a permit-to-work:

Switching off any switch fuse spur, distribution board or mains circuit board that may affect clinical or safety critical systems, the safety of any patient or member of staff or other person working on or visiting the Trust premises;
Work on live apparatus;
Work on electrical distribution systems that need the installed safety systems/barriers defeated or removed;
Work on electrical distribution systems that expose personnel to shock hazards;
Work on remote and automatically controlled low voltage switch-gear
Work on any earthing systems whilst the supply is still live;
Critical System UPS and IPS systems.
Work on complex systems (equipment from more than one source of supply i.e. generators or UPS plus mains)
Requirements given in HTM 06-02, Chapter 7, Tables 1, 2 and
An electrical Permit-to-Work (PTW) is not required for the following work if it is carried out by a Competent Person.
Isolation of electrical distribution systems and equipment to make them safe;
Replacement of electrical outlets, fittings, equipment and fuses where the supply has been made safe;
Installation of new electrical fittings, outlets and equipment.
Final Circuit- being a circuit with one single point of isolation. The isolation must be secured with a safety lock and caution sign.
Low risk tasks may be carried out by semi-skilled operatives under the guidance of a Competent Person. (e.g. the replacement of electrical lamps)
Loss of electrical services

All wards and departments shall carry out a risk assessment for the failure of the electrical supply in their area. This shall identify the course of emergency action to be taken on failure of both lighting and power circuits to ensure the safety of Patients, visitors and staff. Wards should identify in their emergency plans how they will continue to operate on a prolonged power failure and assume that critical systems have failed.
To mitigate the risk of failure of lighting circuits each ward must have at least two torches with spare batteries. The UPS supported power points will be coloured Red.

Emergency access may need to be gained to electrical switchgear. Storerooms and cupboards containing electrical distribution and switchgear (fuse boards) must remain locked and adequate access maintained in case of an emergency requiring electrical supply to be isolated or reinstated.
No combustible materials or any other storage will be kept in any designated room, cupboard or riser with electrical distribution and switchgear.
Safety equipment

When any work under the Trust's Electrical LV or HV safety Rules or related documents and procedures, takes place, appropriate safety equipment and clothing of an approved type shall be issued and used in accordance with the risk assessment in place for the tasks. The competent Person shall ensure that the following equipment is available and used where necessary, during any work on electrical equipment located on Trust premises (including work carried out by authorised contractors):
Rubber gloves;
Safety glasses and face shields;
Rubber mats;
Approved voltage testers;
Insulated tools;
Safety locks
Live working

Work on or near live conductors shall only be permitted in exceptional circumstances and only when a live working permit has been issued by an Electrical Authorised Person. In all other circumstances live working shall be strictly forbidden.

All work on low voltage electrical equipment including conductors should be carried out while such equipment and conductors are dead and isolated from all sources of supply, after being proved dead at the point of work. The only exceptions to this rule are for the circumstances described in HTM  and involve a Competent Person (LV).authorised in writing, working on or near live equipment. The exceptions are:
a) All forms of testing, fault finding or adjustment where practicalities dictate live working is essential
b) The removal and replacement of fuse carriers in final circuits.
c) The removal and replacement of plug in components.
d) Basic battery maintenance (cleaning/topping)
e) Work on battery systems if less than 25v and / or 10Ah (ampere hours).
Control measures

The control measures for the prevention of injury or death from electrical systems will be dependent on the potential risk to employees or patient groups. Where the risk is high or unacceptable, control measures will require to be implemented to provide a safe environment.
General control measures include:
Management and safety procedures are to be strictly followed
Periodic inspection, testing and maintenance of equipment
Instructions are followed where necessary for maintenance, testing and operation of equipment
A log book or similar record system is to be maintained showing details of all maintenance, testing and/or modifications and operation of the equipment
Ensuring only competent staff are allowed to work on appropriate electrical systems or equipment
Tools and equipment used by tradespersons or contractors are certified safe to use
Equipment is suitable and safe for the environment in which it is to be used
All tradespersons have received at least basic First Aid training
Compliance with all Facilities & Information Directorate safety guidelines and allocated procedures and HTM's
Refresher and training updates where appropriate are carried out on a regular basis
Adequate labelling of all equipment after testing
Good lines of communication and clear lines of responsibility
All documentation and recording arrangements
Record retention
It shall be the responsibility of the Authorised Person (HV or LV) to maintain adequate records for the following:
All staff training and authorisation.
Original documents for fixed electrical systems and all subsequent inspection records and maintenance records will be kept available on each specific sites
Tests/work associated with: commissioning, maintenance, inspection, testing and repair of fixed and portable electrical equipment, wiring, switchgear and plant
The Trust's electrical distribution system circuit routes, conductor sizes, switchgear and usage ratings, protection relay settings and control/isolation/final outlet positions
Location of Emergency Battery Lighting supply
Drawings, manuals and test certification for all new/additional work
Incident reporting

Any incident which involves the electrical system and which compromises safety must be reported using the Trust Risk Assessment Form in accordance with the Trust Risk Policy, in the first instance to the Estates & Facilities Department, who will inform the Authorised Person for the system and who in turn will determine what action is to be taken to prevent any risk or danger arising from the reported equipment.
Training requirements
All Authorised Persons (LV) shall be given training in emergency First-Aid and will include the following items:-
Resuscitation for the treatment of electrical shock
Treatment of burns
Control bleeding
Treatment of the unconscious casualty
Contents of First-Aid boxes and kits
Access to a defib
This training shall be repeated every three (3) years.
Monitoring and audit

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and Safety Management group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
